Award.AwardTitle: Ferroelectric Gradient Microfoams as High-Performance Self-Powered Flexible Pressure Sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Flexible pressure sensors hold great application potential in intelligence robots, biomimetic prosthetics and health monitoring. To mimic human skinâ€™s perception of pressure, it is essential that a flexible pressure sensor must be applicable to a broad pressure range aside of its high sensitivity. However, while various transduction mechanisms covering a broad pressure range have been adopted in pressure detection, an unreconciled tradeoff exists between high sensitivity and a broad working range of pressures in the current flexible pressure sensors. This fundamental tradeoff limits the practical applications of the flexible pressure sensors in various healthcare and wearable electronics. This project proposes fundamental research for the development of a new class of flexible ferroelectric sensors that will resolve the tradeoffs. Findings from this project will pave the way toward flexible tactile sensors with high sensitivity over a broad detection range, multi-modal detection capability, and self-powered characteristic, together with remarkable mechanical stability and durability. The educational goal is to foster the multidisciplinary training environment for undergraduate and graduate students and build next-generation workforce who will be well prepared to undertake new scientific and engineering challenges. This project will promote the minority involvement and participation in science and engineering research at Penn State.

Ferroelectric microfoams are mechanically flexible and highly mechanosensitive. However, the pressure sensors based on the foams with uniform porosity lose detection sensitivity beyond the critical load at which the microskeletons in the foam buckle. To overcome this limitation, this research team aims to develop high-performance gradient microfoam sensors. With gradient porosity, the detrimental buckling mode can be shielded by simultaneously activating other deformation modes in the ferroelectric foam, thereby enabling both high sensitivity and broad detection range. An integrated approach, involving multiphysics modeling, materials synthesis, and comprehensive characterization of mechanical, piezoelectric, and sensing properties, will be adopted to fulfill the goals. The multiphysics modeling will identify a set of key parameters that govern mechanical flexibility, detection sensitivity and operation range, which will guide the design and optimization of the gradient foam sensors. The proposed synthesis approach involves the fabrication of the microfoam with gradient porosity followed by grafting of molecular ferroelectric crystals onto the foam. The performance of the sensors will be characterized and demonstrated at different loading regimes and loading modes. This in-depth understanding and characterization will lead to the processing of the gradient ferroelectric microfoam sensors with unprecedented precision and performance. Knowledge generated within this project will also foster transformative progress in broadening applications of molecular ferroelectrics, a newly developed class of electroactive materials, in sensors and other electronic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flexible pressure sensors hold great application potential in intelligence robots, biomimetic prosthetics and health monitoring. While various transduction mechanisms covering a broad pressure range have been adopted in pressure detection, an unreconciled tradeoff exists between high sensitivity and a broad working range of pressures in the current flexible pressure sensors. This project proposes fundamental research for the development of new flexible sensors to resolve this fundamental tradeoff that limits the practical applications of the flexible pressure sensors in various healthcare and wearable electronics.

The flexible sensors based on the polyurethane sponge grafted with the molecular ferroelectric and the liquid metal-filled elastomeric composites have been designed and prepared. The microstructures, and mechanical, piezoelectric and electrical properties of the polyurethane sponges and the elastomeric composites under varied mechanical deformation conditions have been characterized. The project has established the structure-physical property-sensing performance relationship via systematic synthesis and characterization. The project has developed multiscale electro-mechanical models to simulate the piezoelectric responses of the gradient foam sensors and elucidate the underlying mechanisms governing the sensor sensitivity, detection limit, linearity, and durability. The project has developed numerical models to simulate the mechanical and electrical responses of the flexible composite conductors under the external force. The experimental results have been integrated with modeling to establish rules of engineering design and optimization for flexible sensors. This project opens a new direction in the development of high-performance flexible pressure sensors and sheds light on our fundamental understanding of electro-mechanical coupling in polymeric materials which are relevant for a wide range of advanced technologies.

The interdisciplinary project has provided exceptional opportunities for training of graduate and undergraduate students in a variety of techniques and fields: polymers, polymer composites, ferroelectrics, materials and engineering, structural characterization, electric and dielectric measurements, evaluation of sensing performance, and in-depth understanding of structure-property-performance. Students engaged in the project are well-prepared to undertake new scientific and engineering challenges, especially in the interdisciplinary area of sensors. The undergraduate students from the Minority Undergraduate Research Experience (MURE) and Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) have been involved in the project. The “Flexible Polymer Sensors” modules including lecture materials, handouts, slides, and hands-on experimental demonstrations have been developed for courses and outreach activities. The PI has attended open houses and outreach events to promote participation of minority students and high school kids in science learning and career. The PIs and the students has delivered presentations on this project in the national meetings and various universities.
